  • ➤ Side effects of Atypical anti- Psychotics:
  • ➤ Side effects of Atypical anti- Psychotics:
  • ➤ Side effects
  • ➤ Side effects
  • ➤ Cause lipodystrophy syndrome characterized by ↑Glucose ↑Lipids Weight gain Insulin Resistance Risk is highest with clozapine and olanzapine
  • ➤ Cause lipodystrophy syndrome characterized by ↑Glucose ↑Lipids Weight gain Insulin Resistance
  • ➤ ↑Glucose ↑Lipids Weight gain Insulin Resistance
  • ➤ ↑Glucose
  • ➤ ↑Lipids
  • ➤ Weight gain
  • ➤ Insulin Resistance
  • ➤ Risk is highest with clozapine and olanzapine

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Liposomal Amphotericin B plus 5-FC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine (5-FC). This combination is used during the initial induction phase of treatment.
  • • Liposomal amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death.
  • • 5-flucytosine is an antimetabolite that inhibits DNA and protein synthesis in fungal cells. The combination therapy provides synergistic effects against Cryptococcus, especially in the central nervous system infections like meningitis.
  • • Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis typically follows a three-phase approach:
  • • Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis typically follows a three-phase approach:
  • • Induction phase - liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine Consolidation phase - fluconazole Maintenance phase- fluconazole
  • • Induction phase - liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine
  • • Induction phase -
  • • Consolidation phase - fluconazole
  • • Consolidation phase -
  • • Maintenance phase- fluconazole
  • • Maintenance phase-
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is used in the maintenance & Consolidation phase of cryptococcal meningitis treatment, not as the primary drug of choice for acute infection. It's less effective than amphotericin B for the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.
  • • Option A. Fluconazole:
  • • Option C. 5-Flucytosine: While 5-flucytosine is an important component of the treatment regimen for cryptococcal meningitis, it is not used as monotherapy. It has limited efficacy when used alone and is primarily used in combination with amphotericin B to enhance fungicidal activity.
  • • Option C. 5-Flucytosine:
  • • Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is an allylamine antifungal that inhibits squalene epoxidase, interfering with ergosterol synthesis. It is primarily used for dermatophyte infections (tinea infections of skin, hair, and nails).
  • • Option D. Terbinafine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is the combination of liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine for induction therapy, followed by fluconazole for maintenance & Consolidation therapy.

questions.text: A patient was administered succinylcholine and halothane before surgery. The patient developed sudden rigidity. Core temperature was elevated to 104°F, and there was an elevation in EtCO2 as well. Which of the following is the most suitable medication to treat this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dantrolene

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical scenario described is characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, a rare but life-threatening condition that can be triggered by volatile anaesthetic agents (like halothane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (like succinylcholine).
  • • The classic clinical features include muscle rigidity, rapidly increasing body temperature, elevated end-tidal CO2 (due to increased metabolism) and if left untreated, can progress to rhabdomyolysis, acidosis, hyperkalemia and eventually death.
  • • Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. It acts by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, thereby reducing the hypermetabolic state and muscle contraction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sodium bicarbonate: While acidosis may develop during malignant hyperthermia and sodium bicarbonate might be used as a supportive measure to correct metabolic acidosis. Dantrolene specifically targets the calcium dysregulation that is central to malignant hyperthermia.
  • • Option A. Sodium bicarbonate:
  • • Option C. Lorazepam: This is a benzodiazepine used primarily for seizures, anxiety, and sedation. It has no role in the management of malignant hyperthermia and would not address the hypermetabolic crisis.
  • • Option C. Lorazepam:
  • • Option D. Mannitol: This is an osmotic diuretic that might be used as a supportive measure in malignant hyperthermia to prevent or treat renal failure from myoglobinuria (resulting from muscle breakdown). However, like sodium bicarbonate, it is not the specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia.
  • • Option D. Mannitol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant hyperthermia as a potential complication of succinylcholine and halothane administration, Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Indomethacin should not be given with ACE inhibitors because: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyperkalemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ACE inhibitors work by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Aldosterone normally promotes potassium excretion in the distal tubule. When ACE inhibitors block this pathway, aldosterone levels decrease, resulting in reduced potassium excretion and a tendency toward hyperkalemia.
  • • NSAIDs like indomethacin further increase this risk through several mechanisms:
  • • NSAIDs like indomethacin further increase this risk through several mechanisms:
  • • They reduce renal blood flow by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis They decrease glomerular filtration rate (GFR) They impair renin release They directly interfere with potassium excretion
  • • They reduce renal blood flow by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
  • • They decrease glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
  • • They impair renin release
  • • They directly interfere with potassium excretion
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hyponatremia: While ACE inhibitors can occasionally cause hyponatremia by increasing water retention through ADH mechanisms, this is not significantly worsened by the addition of NSAIDs. The primary concern when combining these drug classes is hyperkalemia.
  • • Option B. Hyponatremia:
  • • Option C. Hyperuricemia: Although both ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs can independently affect uric acid levels (NSAIDs can increase uric acid levels by decreasing its excretion), hyperuricemia is not the primary concern when combining these medications. The risk of hyperkalemia is more significant and potentially more dangerous.
  • • Option C. Hyperuricemia:
  • • Option D. It may cause severe hypotension: While both ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs can affect blood pressure, their combined effect typically results in a reduction of the antihypertensive efficacy of ACE inhibitors rather than severe hypotension. NSAIDs tend to increase blood pressure by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, which opposes the blood pressure-lowering effects of ACE inhibitors.
  • • Option D. It may cause severe hypotension:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NSAIDs like indomethacin should not be given with ACE inhibitors due to increased risk of hyperkalemia, as both drug classes can interfere with potassium excretion through different mechanisms.

questions.text: A patient has throbbing unilateral headache and photophobia, which is treated by sumatriptan. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Migraine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Migraine is characterized by unilateral, pulsatile headache often associated with photophobia (sensitivity to light), phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), nausea, and vomiting. Symptoms of "throbbing unilateral headache with photophobia" are classic presentation of migraine.
  • • Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist are the drug of choice for acute severe migraine attacks. They work by:
  • • Causing vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the brain Inhibiting the release of inflammatory neuropeptides, particularly Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP)
  • • Causing vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the brain
  • • Inhibiting the release of inflammatory neuropeptides, particularly Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tension headache: Incorrect because. Tension headaches typically present as bilateral, non-pulsatile, "band-like" pain around the head. They are usually not associated with photophobia and are not typically treated with triptans like sumatriptan. First-line treatments for tension headaches are NSAIDs.
  • • Option B. Tension headache: Incorrect because.
  • • Option C. Cluster headache: Incorrect because. Cluster headaches, while unilateral, are extremely severe and often described as "boring" or "stabbing" rather than throbbing. They are typically associated with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms like lacrimation, nasal congestion, or rhinorrhoea. While triptans can be used for cluster headaches, first-line treatments usually include high-flow oxygen therapy.
  • • Option C. Cluster headache: Incorrect because.
  • • Option D. Frontal headache: Incorrect because. "Frontal headache" refers to pain localized to the frontal region of the head and can be a symptom of various conditions including sinusitis, tension headache, or migraine.
  • • Option D. Frontal headache: Incorrect because.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of acute attack:
  • ➤ Treatment of acute attack:
  • ➤ Drug of choice for mild to moderate headache – NSAIDs (Paracetamol, diclofenac) Drug of choice for Acute severe attack – Triptans Other drug for Acute severe migraine – Ergotamine
  • ➤ Drug of choice for mild to moderate headache – NSAIDs (Paracetamol, diclofenac)
  • ➤ Drug of choice for Acute severe attack – Triptans
  • ➤ Other drug for Acute severe migraine – Ergotamine

questions.text: A tissue sample shows significant cellular damage. Which of the following changes is most indicative of irreversible cell injury in the sample? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amorphous density of mitochondria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The presence of amorphous densities in mitochondria is a morphological feature that indicates irreversible cell injury, distinguishing it from changes that can be seen in both reversible and irreversible injury such as cellular swelling, bleb formation, and cytoplasmic vacuolation.

questions.text: A patient with a bleeding disorder is suspected of having von Willebrand disease. What does vWF primarily bind to in the process of platelet adhesion? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gp Ib/IX

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to glycoprotein Ib/IX (GpIb/IX) on platelets during the initial adhesion process, which is essential for normal hemostasis. Deficiency or dysfunction of VWF results in von Willebrand disease, characterized by mucocutaneous bleeding due to impaired platelet adhesion.

questions.text: Which family member is responsible for transmission of the disease in mitochondrial inheritance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mother

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal transmission pattern in which only mothers can pass mitochondrial DNA mutations to their children. This occurs because all mitochondria in humans are inherited from the mother's egg cell, while paternal mitochondria are eliminated during fertilization.

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vestibulospinal tract is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and posture by integrating vestibular system input and facilitating extensor muscle activity to stabilize the body during motion and positional changes. It plays a crucial role in postural adjustments following vestibular disturbances, such as those experienced after rapid or erratic motion, like a roller coaster ride.
  • ➤ maintaining balance and posture

questions.text: Identify the pointed structure shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right Hepatic artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Right Hepatic artery is a branch of the proper hepatic artery that supplies the right lobe of the liver. It is an important anatomical structure in hepatobiliary surgery, as it gives rise to the cystic artery within Calot's triangle.
  • ➤ Right Hepatic artery

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pouch of Douglas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pouch of Douglas is the rectouterine pouch, the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in females, where pathological fluid collections are often found during clinical evaluation.

questions.text: A patient has an urge to urinate but he is not able to do. He has history of a fall astride injury. On examination blood is seen at meatus. Which of the following injury is most common? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bulbar urethra rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bulbar urethral rupture is the most common site of urethral injury in straddle injuries, presenting with blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma, and urinary retention.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blastocyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The blastocyst is a key structure in early human development that forms around day 5 post-fertilization and is essential for implantation. It consists of a trophoblast and an inner cell mass, which give rise to the placenta and embryo, respectively.

questions.text: Identify the congenital abnormality shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Open Neural Tube Defect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Open Neural Tube Defects (ONTDs) result from incomplete closure of the neural tube during early development. They can manifest in various forms, including myelomeningocele and anencephaly, depending on the site of the defect. Adequate maternal folate supplementation is critical for reducing the risk of ONTDs.

questions.text: Identify the cell shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Purkinje cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purkinje cells are large, flask-shaped neurons located in the Purkinje layer of the cerebellum. They play a critical role in motor coordination by integrating multiple inputs and sending inhibitory signals to the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elastic cartilage is identified by the presence of elastic fibers within its matrix, which provides flexibility and strength. It is found in the pinna of the ear, epiglottis, and Eustachian tube.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thymus

questions.text: A child present with congenital defect in diaphragm which is located on posterior/postero-lateral aspect of chest. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bochdalek hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, characterized by a posterior or posterolateral defect in the diaphragm, usually on the left side . It results from the failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close and leads to pulmonary hypoplasia due to the herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity.
  • ➤ posterior or posterolateral defect
  • ➤ left side
  • ➤ pulmonary hypoplasia

questions.text: In a patient, eye blinking occurs when a doctor touches the eye with a piece of cotton. Which of the following nerves is responsible for carrying sensation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) V CN (Trigeminal Nerve)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trigeminal nerve (CN V) carries sensory information from the face and eye region, while the facial nerve (CN VII) provides motor innervation for facial expressions including blinking.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: (FMGE JAN 2025) pH: 7.50 PaCO₂: 48 mmHg HCO₃: 33 mmol/L What is the most likely acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient has metabolic alkalosis due to:
  • • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia. Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis. Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa , a psychiatric illness. Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis : Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16 In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia.
  • • pH
  • • Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis.
  • • HCO₃
  • • Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • • Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa , a psychiatric illness.
  • • bulimia nervosa
  • • Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis : Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16 In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • PaCO₂
  • • Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis
  • • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16 In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
  • • 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20
  • • 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
  • • In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2) So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg.
  • • 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2)
  • • So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg.
  • • The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Metabolic acidosis : Incorrect, as this would present with low pH (<7.4) and low HCO₃ (<24)
  • • Option A. Metabolic acidosis
  • • low pH
  • • low HCO₃ (<24)
  • • Option C. Respiratory acidosis : Incorrect, as the patient’s pH is 7.5 (alkalotic) and in acidosis pH would generally be low (< 7.4)
  • • Option C. Respiratory acidosis
  • • Option D. Respiratory alkalosis : Incorrect, as this would present with low PaCO₂ (< 40) and high pH (>7.4)
  • • Option D. Respiratory alkalosis
  • • low PaCO₂

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic vomiting results in loss of chloride (in the vomitus), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic Alkalosis is usually characterized by elevated pH and HCO₃ , with appropriate respiratory compensation ( elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation ).
  • ➤ Chronic vomiting
  • ➤ elevated pH and HCO₃
  • ➤ elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation

questions.text: What is the most likely underlying condition associated with the Graham Steell murmur? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary regurgitation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Graham Steell murmur is a characteristic early diastolic murmur caused by pulmonary regurgitation in the setting of pulmonary hypertension . It occurs when increased pulmonary artery pressure causes dilation of the pulmonary valve ring , leading to incompetence and regurgitation. The murmur is best heard in the left second or third intercostal space and is characterized as an early diastolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur that decreases in intensity during inspiration.
  • • early diastolic murmur
  • • pulmonary regurgitation
  • • pulmonary hypertension
  • • increased pulmonary artery pressure
  • • pulmonary valve ring
  • • best heard in the left second or third intercostal space
  • • early diastolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ventricular septal defect (VSD) : Produces a pansystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border . A small VSD producing a loud murmur is called Maladie de Roger , not Graham Steell murmur .
  • • Option B. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • • pansystolic murmur
  • • left lower sternal border
  • • Maladie de Roger
  • • Graham Steell murmur
  • • Option C. Pulmonary stenosis: Produces an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the pulmonary area (left upper sternal border) . It does not produce a diastolic murmur , which is characteristic of Graham Steell murmur .
  • • Option C. Pulmonary stenosis:
  • • ejection systolic murmur
  • • pulmonary area (left upper sternal border)
  • • does not produce a diastolic murmur
  • • Graham Steell murmur
  • • Option D. Mitral stenosis: Produces a mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex , with presystolic accentuation . It is associated with rheumatic heart disease and does not cause an early diastolic murmur characteristic of Graham Steell.
  • • Option D. Mitral stenosis:
  • • mid-diastolic murmur
  • • apex
  • • presystolic accentuation
  • • rheumatic heart disease
  • • does not cause an early diastolic murmur

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Graham Steell murmur is a high-pitched early diastolic murmur caused by pulmonary regurgitation in the setting of pulmonary hypertension .
  • ➤ high-pitched early diastolic murmur
  • ➤ pulmonary regurgitation
  • ➤ pulmonary hypertension

  • • Hyperdynamic apex
  • • volume overload conditions
  • • History of rheumatic heart disease , which commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves
  • • History of rheumatic heart disease
  • • commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations and giddiness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardioversion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a case of atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability . The diagnosis is supported by:
  • • atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability
  • • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output
  • • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF
  • • ECG findings
  • • irregularly irregular RR interval
  • • AF
  • • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise
  • • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg)
  • • hemodynamic compromise
  • • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output
  • • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness
  • • In any tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability ( systolic BP < 90 mmHg ), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice , regardless of the specific arrhythmia. This is because unstable blood pressure indicates that the patient is in shock and requires immediate rhythm restoration.
  • • tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability
  • • systolic BP < 90 mmHg
  • • immediate synchronized cardioversion
  • • treatment of choice
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Adenosine: Incorrect
  • • Option A. Adenosine:
  • • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia) Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)
  • • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia)
  • • Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)
  • • Option B. Verapamil: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Verapamil:
  • • Useful in rate control for stable AF Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients
  • • Useful in rate control for stable AF
  • • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension
  • • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients
  • • Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients
  • • Option C. Amiodarone: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Amiodarone:
  • • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients
  • • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action
  • • Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability
  • • Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability ( systolic BP < 90 mmHg ), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia type.
  • ➤ tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability
  • ➤ systolic BP < 90 mmHg
  • ➤ immediate synchronized cardioversion

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding first-degree AV block? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave

options.label: B
options.text: Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex

options.label: D
options.text: Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave

questions.correct_answer: B. Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • First-degree AV block is characterized by prolongation of the PR interval ( >0.2 seconds or >200 milliseconds ) with each P wave being followed by a QRS complex . This represents a delay in conduction through the AV node , but every atrial impulse still successfully conducts to the ventricles . On ECG , this appears as more than five small boxes between the P wave and QRS complex .
  • • AV block
  • • prolongation of the PR interval
  • • >0.2 seconds or >200 milliseconds
  • • each P wave being followed by a QRS complex
  • • AV node
  • • every atrial impulse still successfully conducts to the ventricles
  • • ECG
  • • more than five small boxes
  • • P wave and QRS complex
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect
  • • Option A. Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave:
  • • Describes Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block , where PR lengthens progressively until a P wave fails to conduct
  • • Describes Mobitz
  • • type I (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block , where PR lengthens progressively until a P wave fails to conduct
  • • type I (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block
  • • PR lengthens progressively until a P wave fails to conduct
  • • Option C. Presence of atrioventricular dissociation: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Presence of atrioventricular dissociation:
  • • Seen in third-degree (complete) heart block , where the atria and ventricles beat independently P waves and QRS complexes have no relation to each other
  • • Seen in third-degree (complete) heart block , where the atria and ventricles beat independently
  • • Seen in third-degree (complete) heart block
  • • atria and ventricles beat independently
  • • P waves and QRS complexes have no relation to each other
  • • Option D. Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave:
  • • Describes Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, where PR remains constant but occasional P waves fail to conduct
  • • Describes Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, where PR remains constant but occasional P waves fail to conduct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.2 seconds) with 1:1 conduction , where each P wave is followed by a QRS complex .
  • ➤ First-degree AV block
  • ➤ prolonged PR interval (>0.2 seconds)
  • ➤ 1:1 conduction
  • ➤ each P wave is followed by a QRS complex

questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, the a-wave corresponds to: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The a-wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform corresponds to atrial contraction . When the right atrium contracts , it causes an increase in pressure , which is transmitted backward into the jugular veins , creating the a-wave . This wave appears just before the carotid pulse and the first heart sound (S1) .
  • • a-wave
  • • jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform
  • • atrial contraction
  • • right atrium contracts
  • • increase in pressure
  • • jugular veins
  • • a-wave
  • • appears just before the carotid pulse and the first heart sound (S1)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ventricular contraction: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Ventricular contraction:
  • • Ventricular contraction corresponds to the c-wave in the JVP waveform, caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
  • • Ventricular contraction corresponds to the c-wave in the JVP waveform, caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
  • • Ventricular contraction corresponds to the c-wave
  • • bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
  • • Option C. Passive atrial filling: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Passive atrial filling:
  • • Corresponds to the v-wave in the JVP waveform Occurs during ventricular systole when the tricuspid valve is closed and blood continues to flow into the right atrium from the venae cavae
  • • Corresponds to the v-wave in the JVP waveform
  • • Corresponds to the v-wave
  • • Occurs during ventricular systole when the tricuspid valve is closed and blood continues to flow into the right atrium from the venae cavae
  • • Occurs during ventricular systole
  • • tricuspid valve is closed
  • • flow into the right atrium from the venae cavae
  • • Option D. Tricuspid valve closure: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Tricuspid valve closure:
  • • Associated with the c-wave , not a distinct wave of its own
  • • Associated with the c-wave , not a distinct wave of its own
  • • Associated with the c-wave

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The a-wave in the JVP waveform corresponds to atrial contraction and is a key marker of normal atrial function .
  • ➤ a-wave in the JVP waveform
  • ➤ atrial contraction
  • ➤ key marker of normal atrial function

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with persistent hypertension. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated aldosterone levels with suppressed renin activity. Which of the following findings is not seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sodium loss

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Primary hyperaldosteronism presents with hypertension and elevated aldosterone levels with suppressed renin activity . Key features:
  • • Primary hyperaldosteronism
  • • hypertension and elevated aldosterone levels
  • • suppressed renin activity
  • • Increased sodium reabsorption → Sodium retention (NOT loss) Increased potassium excretion → Hypokalemia Metabolic alkalosis → Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion Muscle cramps → Due to hypokalemia and electrolyte imbalance
  • • Increased sodium reabsorption → Sodium retention (NOT loss)
  • • Increased sodium reabsorption
  • • Sodium retention (NOT loss)
  • • Increased potassium excretion → Hypokalemia
  • • Increased potassium excretion
  • • Hypokalemia
  • • Metabolic alkalosis → Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion
  • • Metabolic alkalosis
  • • Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion
  • • Muscle cramps → Due to hypokalemia and electrolyte imbalance
  • • Muscle cramps
  • • Due to hypokalemia and electrolyte imbalance
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia: Incorrect, as it is a classic finding in primary hyperaldosteronism due to increased urinary potassium excretion
  • • Option A. Hypokalemia:
  • • classic finding
  • • primary hyperaldosteronism
  • • increased urinary potassium excretion
  • • Option C. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect, as it occurs due to hydrogen ion loss and potassium depletion
  • • Option C. Metabolic alkalosis:
  • • hydrogen ion loss and potassium depletion
  • • Option D. Muscle cramps: Incorrect, as they are commonly seen in primary hyperaldosteronism , primarily due to hypokalemia
  • • Option D. Muscle cramps:
  • • commonly seen in primary hyperaldosteronism
  • • hypokalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary hyperaldosteronism causes sodium retention (not sodium loss) and presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and muscle cramps .
  • ➤ Primary hyperaldosteronism causes sodium retention (not sodium loss)
  • ➤ hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and muscle cramps

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker presents with a history of progressive dyspnea and chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) reveal the following: (FMGE JAN 2025) Decreased FEV₁ Decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio (<70%) Minimal improvement in FEV₁ after bronchodilator therapy What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This case presents a classic presentation of COPD with the following diagnostic features:
  • • classic presentation of COPD
  • • History of smoking (major risk factor) Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough (typical symptoms) PFT findings: Decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic of obstructive airway disease) Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response ( distinguishing it from asthma, which shows significant bronchodilator response )
  • • History of smoking (major risk factor)
  • • History of smoking
  • • Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough (typical symptoms)
  • • Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough
  • • PFT findings: Decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic of obstructive airway disease) Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response ( distinguishing it from asthma, which shows significant bronchodilator response )
  • • PFT findings:
  • • Decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic of obstructive airway disease) Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response ( distinguishing it from asthma, which shows significant bronchodilator response )
  • • Decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic of obstructive airway disease)
  • • Decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio <70%
  • • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response ( distinguishing it from asthma, which shows significant bronchodilator response )
  • • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response
  • • distinguishing it from asthma, which shows significant bronchodilator response
  • • According to the GOLD criteria , a post-bronchodilator FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% confirms COPD in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.
  • • GOLD criteria
  • • post-bronchodilator FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% confirms COPD
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis:

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with mitral stenosis is being evaluated. Which clinical finding best indicates the severity of the condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)

  • • heart failure, mitral regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The S2-OS interval is the best clinical indicator of mitral stenosis severity, as a shorter interval reflects higher left atrial pressure and more severe disease progression.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with both TB and AIDS is started on antiretroviral therapy (ART). Shortly after, he experiences a worsening of symptoms, including fever and malaise. What is the most likely cause of this clinical deterioration? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • IRIS occurs after initiating ART in HIV patients with an underlying opportunistic infection (e.g., TB).
  • • IRIS occurs after initiating ART in HIV patients with an underlying opportunistic infection (e.g., TB).
  • • Pathophysiology: Before ART: Severe immunosuppression limits the immune response against TB After ART initiation: Rapid immune restoration triggers an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing but previously unrecognized TB Result: Clinical worsening with fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms
  • • Pathophysiology: Before ART: Severe immunosuppression limits the immune response against TB After ART initiation: Rapid immune restoration triggers an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing but previously unrecognized TB Result: Clinical worsening with fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms

  • • Before ART: Severe immunosuppression limits the immune response against TB After ART initiation: Rapid immune restoration triggers an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing but previously unrecognized TB Result: Clinical worsening with fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms
  • • Before ART: Severe immunosuppression limits the immune response against TB
  • • Before ART:
  • • After ART initiation: Rapid immune restoration triggers an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing but previously unrecognized TB
  • • After ART initiation:
  • • exaggerated inflammatory response
  • • Result: Clinical worsening with fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms
  • • Result:
  • • Types of IRIS:
  • • Types of IRIS:
  • • Paradoxical IRIS: Worsening of TB symptoms despite adequate treatment Unmasking IRIS: New onset TB symptoms after ART initiation
  • • Paradoxical IRIS: Worsening of TB symptoms despite adequate treatment
  • • Paradoxical IRIS:
  • • despite adequate treatment
  • • Unmasking IRIS: New onset TB symptoms after ART initiation
  • • Unmasking IRIS:

  • • Option A. Drug interaction between ATT and ART

  • • not cause fever and malaise
  • • Option B. Resistance to MTB: Would cause persistent infection , not acute worsening
  • • Option B. Resistance to MTB:
  • • persistent infection
  • • Option D. Development of extrapulmonary TB: IRIS can exacerbate existing TB , but it is not a new TB infection
  • • Option D. Development of extrapulmonary TB:
  • • exacerbate existing TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) occurs after ART initiation, leading to an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing infections.

questions.text: A patient with decompensated liver cirrhosis presents with difficulty breathing due to significant ascites accumulation. Which of the following statements regarding the evaluation and cause of ascites is incorrect? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: C. The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically less than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites

  • • portal hypertension
  • • increases hydrostatic pressure
  • • peritoneal cavity

  • • SAAG classification:
  • • SAAG > 1.1 g/dL → Portal hypertension-related ascites (e.g., cirrhosis, heart failure, Budd-Chiari syndrome) SAAG < 1.1 g/dL → Non-portal hypertension causes (e.g., malignancy, tuberculosis, pancreatitis)

  • • SAAG > 1.1 g/dL

  • • SAAG < 1.1 g/dL → Non-portal hypertension causes (e.g., malignancy, tuberculosis, pancreatitis)
  • • SAAG < 1.1 g/dL
  • • Non-portal hypertension causes
  • • Since cirrhosis-related ascites results from increased portal pressure , SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL .
  • • cirrhosis-related ascites results from increased portal pressure
  • • typically >1.1 g/dL
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism: Correct; cirrhosis leads to RAAS activation , causing sodium and water retention
  • • Option A. Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism:
  • • RAAS activation
  • • Option B. Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary: Correct; SAAG is calculated using these values
  • • Option B. Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary:
  • • Option D. SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites: Correct, as it reflects portal hypertension
  • • Option D. SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites:
  • • portal hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The SAAG value helps differentiate portal hypertension-related ascites (>1.1 g/dL) from non-portal hypertension causes (<1.1 g/dL).

questions.text: Based on the given X-ray image, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The X-ray shows free air under both domes of diaphragm, which is pathognomonic of hollow viscus perforation. This occurs when there is a breach in the wall of a hollow organ (like stomach or intestine) leading to escape of air into the peritoneal cavity. The free air rises and collects under the diaphragm, visible as a dark area on chest X-ray when the patient is erect X-ray.
  • • The common causes include:
  • • The common causes include:
  • • Peptic ulcer perforation (most common) Traumatic bowel injury Typhoid ileal perforation Appendicular perforation
  • • Peptic ulcer perforation (most common)
  • • Traumatic bowel injury
  • • Typhoid ileal perforation
  • • Appendicular perforation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sub-acute intestinal obstruction : Incorrect because X-ray would show dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels, not free air under the diaphragm
  • • Option A. Sub-acute intestinal obstruction
  • • Option B. Paralytic ileus : Incorrect as X-ray would show dilated bowel loops with air throughout, no free air under diaphragm
  • • Option B. Paralytic ileus
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion : Incorrect as X-ray would show homogeneous opacity in pleural space with obliteration of costophrenic angles, not free air under diaphragm
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation is diagnosed radiologically by the presence of free air under the diaphragm, typically seen in an erect chest X-ray or CT scan of the abdomen. It is a surgical emergency requiring immediate laparotomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia, which is more pronounced for liquids than solids. A barium swallow study is performed. Which characteristic radiological finding is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rat tail deformity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia:
  • • Young patient (25 years) Dysphagia to both liquids and solids, with liquids being affected more In achalasia, barium swallow characteristically shows a "bird beak" or "rat tail" appearance due to smooth tapering at the gastroesophageal junction with proximal dilation of esophagus This appearance is due to failure of LES relaxation with preserved peristalsis in body of esophagus, which is the hallmark of achalasia
  • • Young patient (25 years)
  • • Dysphagia to both liquids and solids, with liquids being affected more
  • • In achalasia, barium swallow characteristically shows a "bird beak" or "rat tail" appearance due to smooth tapering at the gastroesophageal junction with proximal dilation of esophagus
  • • This appearance is due to failure of LES relaxation with preserved peristalsis in body of esophagus, which is the hallmark of achalasia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Smooth filling defect : Incorrect as this suggests a benign mass/tumor
  • • Option B. Smooth filling defect
  • • Option C. Irregular filling defect : Incorrect as this suggests malignant mass causing infiltration of the esophageal wall
  • • Option C. Irregular filling defect
  • • Option D. Corkscrew esophagus : Incorrect as this is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm where the primary symptom is chest pain rather than dysphagia
  • • Option D. Corkscrew esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rat tail/bird beak appearance on barium swallow is characteristic of achalasia cardia, which presents with dysphagia to liquids more than solids.

questions.text: A patient complains of epigastric pain radiating to back after alcohol binge for the last 48 hours. What is the next step? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Serum amylase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical scenario describes a classic presentation of acute pancreatitis. The patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back following an alcohol binge. Alcohol is the second most common cause of acute pancreatitis after gallstones. The first step in diagnosing acute pancreatitis is to check pancreatic enzyme levels in the blood.
  • • Serum amylase rises early (within 4-6 hours) after the onset of acute pancreatitis and is part of the initial workup. Though serum lipase is more specific and remains elevated longer (12-24 hours), amylase is still widely used as the first investigation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. USG abdomen : While ultrasound is useful to evaluate for gallstones as a cause of pancreatitis, it's not the first investigation in suspected acute pancreatitis. USG is typically performed after confirming the diagnosis with pancreatic enzymes.
  • • Option B. USG abdomen
  • • Option C. CECT abdomen: CT scan is not indicated initially and should be performed only after 72 hours of symptom onset if the diagnosis is uncertain or to assess for complications.
  • • Option C. CECT abdomen:
  • • Option D. X-ray abdomen : X-ray has limited utility in diagnosing acute pancreatitis. It may show some non-specific findings like "sentinel loop sign, colon cut-off sign, renal halo sign, gasless abdomen.
  • • Option D. X-ray abdomen

questions.text: Which anatomical structure is marked in the given image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • The image shows Calot's triangle anatomy where:
  • • Right hepatic artery is a branch of common hepatic artery It gives off the cystic artery which supplies the gallbladder The artery marked in the image is entering the liver, making it the right hepatic artery Mistaking the right hepatic artery for the cystic artery during surgery can lead to catastrophic haemorrhage or liver ischemia.
  • • Right hepatic artery is a branch of common hepatic artery
  • • It gives off the cystic artery which supplies the gallbladder
  • • The artery marked in the image is entering the liver, making it the right hepatic artery
  • • Mistaking the right hepatic artery for the cystic artery during surgery can lead to catastrophic haemorrhage or liver ischemia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cystic artery : Incorrect as cystic artery is a branch of right hepatic artery that supplies the gallbladder, not the vessel marked which is entering liver
  • • Option A. Cystic artery
  • • Option B. Cystic duct : Incorrect as cystic duct drains gallbladder and joins common hepatic duct to form common bile duct
  • • Option B. Cystic duct
  • • Option D. Hepatic duct : Incorrect as hepatic ducts are biliary drainage channels, not arteries
  • • Option D. Hepatic duct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The right hepatic artery is a key structure in hepatobiliary surgery, running within Calot’s Triangle and supplying the right lobe of the liver. Identifying it correctly during cholecystectomy is crucial to avoid vascular injury.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with dilated, tortuous veins in the leg. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)

  • • Option C. Sclerotherapy is the first-line treatment : Incorrect as sclerotherapy is primarily used for small reticular veins and telangiectasias, not for large varicose veins

  • • Option D. Compression stockings are curative:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) is an effective, first-line treatment for symptomatic varicose veins. Compression stockings provide symptom relief but are not curative.

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with vomiting and constipation. On examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)

Best initial test : Ultrasound abdomen → Shows a thickened pyloric muscle (> 4mm thick, > 16mm long). Treatment : Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy (surgical incision of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle).

questions.text: During laparoscopic surgery, which vessels are most prone to injury while inserting trocars? (FMGE JAN 2025)

It is commonly injured during trocar placement at the lateral ports (midclavicular line or lateral to rectus muscle) . Superior Epigastric Artery (SEA) → Arises from the internal thoracic artery , supplying the upper abdominal wall . It is less commonly injured but still at risk in upper trocar insertions near the midline .

Rule of 2’s: Found in 2% of the population . 2 feet from the ileocecal valve . 2 inches long . 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic). 2:1 male predominance . Complications: Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa , leading to ulceration. Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception). Diverticulitis , mimicking appendicitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presented with painless right scrotal swelling for 2 months. The left testis was normal. There were enlarged para-aortic nodes. USG showed right testicular mass. What will be the management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High inguinal orchiectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a classic presentation of testicular tumor (likely seminoma) with para-aortic lymph node metastasis. High inguinal orchiectomy is the standard initial management. The procedure involves removing the entire testis with spermatic cord through an inguinal incision. This approach is crucial because:
  • • It allows control of lymphatic and vascular supply at the deep inguinal ring Prevents tumor spillage and local spread Avoids breaching the scrotum which could lead to tumor seeding Helps maintain proper oncological principles
  • • It allows control of lymphatic and vascular supply at the deep inguinal ring
  • • Prevents tumor spillage and local spread
  • • Avoids breaching the scrotum which could lead to tumor seeding
  • • Helps maintain proper oncological principles
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Biopsy of scrotal mass - Incorrect
  • • Option A. Biopsy of scrotal mass
  • • Biopsy or FNAC is contraindicated in testicular tumors as it may cause tumor spillage and upstaging Can lead to scrotal violation and altered lymphatic drainage
  • • Biopsy or FNAC is contraindicated in testicular tumors as it may cause tumor spillage and upstaging
  • • Can lead to scrotal violation and altered lymphatic drainage
  • • Option C. Scrotal orchiectomy - Incorrect
  • • Option C. Scrotal orchiectomy
  • • Associated with high risk of local recurrence Breaches scrotal skin which can lead to tumor seeding Changes the lymphatic drainage pattern Can cause upstaging of the tumor
  • • Associated with high risk of local recurrence
  • • Breaches scrotal skin which can lead to tumor seeding
  • • Changes the lymphatic drainage pattern
  • • Can cause upstaging of the tumor
  • • Option D. Biopsy of lymph node - Incorrect
  • • Option D. Biopsy of lymph node
  • • Not needed at initial diagnosis Primary management is always removal of the testicular mass Para-aortic nodes are consistent with the natural lymphatic spread pattern Further staging can be done after orchiectomy
  • • Not needed at initial diagnosis
  • • Primary management is always removal of the testicular mass
  • • Para-aortic nodes are consistent with the natural lymphatic spread pattern
  • • Further staging can be done after orchiectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High inguinal orchiectomy is the standard initial management for testicular tumors. Scrotal violation must be avoided to prevent tumor spillage and upstaging.

  • • Does not exist in clinical practice No requirement for fourth lumen
  • • Does not exist in clinical practice
  • • No requirement for fourth lumen

  • • Option C. 22 French Foley's 2 lumen catheter

  • • Option D. 22 French Foley's 1 lumen catheter
  • • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel No irrigation capability Inadequate for managing clots Not practical for this clinical scenario
  • • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel

questions.text: A patient presents six months after an abdominal hysterectomy with a swelling at the scar site. Initially reducible, the swelling has now become irreducible and tender. The rest of the abdomen is normal on palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bowel strangulation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a case of strangulated incisional hernia because:
  • • History of previous surgery (hysterectomy) leading to incisional hernia Initially reducible swelling suggests hernia Progression to irreducibility with tenderness indicates strangulation Strangulation occurs when blood supply to herniated bowel is compromised Requires urgent surgical intervention to prevent bowel gangrene
  • • History of previous surgery (hysterectomy) leading to incisional hernia
  • • Initially reducible swelling suggests hernia
  • • Progression to irreducibility with tenderness indicates strangulation
  • • Strangulation occurs when blood supply to herniated bowel is compromised
  • • Requires urgent surgical intervention to prevent bowel gangrene
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Paralytic ileus : Incorrect
  • • Option A. Paralytic ileus
  • • Presents with generalized abdominal distention, not localized swelling No history of recent surgery or precipitating factors Usually associated with absent bowel sounds Does not present as reducible turning irreducible swelling
  • • Presents with generalized abdominal distention, not localized swelling
  • • No history of recent surgery or precipitating factors
  • • Usually associated with absent bowel sounds
  • • Does not present as reducible turning irreducible swelling
  • • Option B. Perforation peritonitis : Incorrect
  • • Option B. Perforation peritonitis
  • • Presents with generalized abdominal pain and distention Associated with severe systemic symptoms Shows signs of peritonitis all over abdomen Not localized to surgical scar
  • • Presents with generalized abdominal pain and distention
  • • Associated with severe systemic symptoms
  • • Shows signs of peritonitis all over abdomen
  • • Not localized to surgical scar
  • • Option D. Ascites : Incorrect
  • • Option D. Ascites
  • • Causes generalized abdominal distention Fluid collects in dependent areas Shows shifting dullness Not localized to surgical scar
  • • Causes generalized abdominal distention
  • • Fluid collects in dependent areas
  • • Shows shifting dullness
  • • Not localized to surgical scar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A previously reducible hernia becoming irreducible with tenderness indicates strangulation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and is diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia without atypia based on an endometrial biopsy. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Remember that LNG-IUS is the preferred treatment for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia due to its local progesterone delivery, which causes endometrial atrophy. This condition has a lower risk of malignancy (~1%) compared to hyperplasia with atypia, which requires hysterectomy.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a difficult prolonged labor where she says the baby was stuck for a long time; followed by cesarean section presents watery vaginal discharge on the 7th post operative day. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)

Educational Objective:

Prevention involves prolonged catheterization (2-3 weeks) in cases of obstructed labor to allow continuous bladder drainage and proper bladder healing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with persistent nasal congestion, foul-smelling greenish-black nasal crusts, and anosmia. Examination reveals a dry nasal cavity with crust formation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation strongly suggests atrophic rhinitis.
  • • The presence of foul-smelling greenish-black discharge (due to Klebsiella ozaenae infection) Anosmia (due to atrophy of nerve elements) Crusting in nasal cavity (due to transformation of normal ciliated columnar epithelium to abnormal stratified squamous epithelium) Female patient (consistent with demographics as atrophic rhinitis commonly affects females) The disease process involves atrophy of nasal mucosa, leading to loss of defense mechanisms (cilia and mucous glands), resulting in secondary infections and crust formation.

  • • While the first stage can mimic atrophic rhinitis, it typically doesn't present with anosmia Characterized by painless nodules giving woody feel ("woody nose" or "hebra nose") Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

  • • Option D. Allergic rhinitis

  • • Presents with sneezing, itching, and watery discharge
  • • IgE-mediated type 1 hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman from Nagaland presents with right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, there is a dull tympanic membrane, and lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck are palpable. She is from a region endemic for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. What is the most appropriate management for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiotherapy (RT)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Radiotherapy is the most appropriate management because:
  • • The presentation suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with: Unilateral hearing loss due to serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane) Painless cervical lymphadenopathy Patient from endemic region (Nagaland) Nasopharyngeal carcinomas are highly radiosensitive tumors This is the first-line treatment for nasopharyngeal carcinoma Radiotherapy provides better outcomes compared to surgery due to: Difficult surgical access to nasopharynx High risk of complications with surgery Rich lymphatic drainage of the area
  • • The presentation suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with: Unilateral hearing loss due to serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane) Painless cervical lymphadenopathy Patient from endemic region (Nagaland)
  • • Unilateral hearing loss due to serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane) Painless cervical lymphadenopathy Patient from endemic region (Nagaland)
  • • Unilateral hearing loss due to serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane)
  • • Painless cervical lymphadenopathy
  • • Patient from endemic region (Nagaland)
  • • Nasopharyngeal carcinomas are highly radiosensitive tumors
  • • This is the first-line treatment for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • • Radiotherapy provides better outcomes compared to surgery due to: Difficult surgical access to nasopharynx High risk of complications with surgery Rich lymphatic drainage of the area
  • • Difficult surgical access to nasopharynx High risk of complications with surgery Rich lymphatic drainage of the area
  • • Difficult surgical access to nasopharynx
  • • High risk of complications with surgery
  • • Rich lymphatic drainage of the area
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Radical neck dissection
  • • Option A. Radical neck dissection
  • • Only addresses lymph node metastases Doesn't treat the primary tumor Not first-line treatment without prior radiotherapy
  • • Only addresses lymph node metastases
  • • Doesn't treat the primary tumor
  • • Not first-line treatment without prior radiotherapy
  • • Option B. Grommet insertion with steroids
  • • Option B. Grommet insertion with steroids
  • • Only treats the secondary middle ear effusion Doesn't address the underlying malignancy Can be considered as supportive treatment for hearing loss
  • • Only treats the secondary middle ear effusion
  • • Doesn't address the underlying malignancy
  • • Can be considered as supportive treatment for hearing loss
  • • Option D. Wait and watch
  • • Option D. Wait and watch
  • • Inappropriate for suspected malignancy Delays definitive treatment Can lead to disease progression
  • • Inappropriate for suspected malignancy
  • • Delays definitive treatment
  • • Can lead to disease progression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiotherapy is the primary treatment modality for nasopharyngeal carcinoma due to the tumor's high radiosensitivity and anatomical considerations.
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

questions.text: A pure tone audiometry (PTA) result shows an air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds. What is the most likely type of hearing loss? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conductive hearing loss (CHL)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The PTA findings indicate conductive hearing loss because:
  • • Bone conduction is normal (within 25 dB threshold). Air conduction is affected (elevated threshold). There is a gap between air and bone conduction curves. This pattern indicates that sound transmission through the external/middle ear is impaired while inner ear function is normal. The presence of air-bone gap with normal bone conduction is pathognomonic of conductive hearing loss.
  • • Bone conduction is normal (within 25 dB threshold).
  • • Air conduction is affected (elevated threshold).
  • • There is a gap between air and bone conduction curves.
  • • This pattern indicates that sound transmission through the external/middle ear is impaired while inner ear function is normal.
  • • The presence of air-bone gap with normal bone conduction is pathognomonic of conductive hearing loss.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  • • Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  • • Both air and bone conduction would be affected No significant air-bone gap Curves would be close to each other in affected range
  • • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • • No significant air-bone gap
  • • Curves would be close to each other in affected range
  • • Option C. Mixed hearing loss
  • • Option C. Mixed hearing loss
  • • Both air and bone conduction would be affected Air-bone gap present but bone conduction also abnormal Both curves would be in affected range with a gap between them
  • • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • • Air-bone gap present but bone conduction also abnormal
  • • Both curves would be in affected range with a gap between them
  • • Option D. Normal hearing
  • • Option D. Normal hearing
  • • Both air and bone conduction would be within normal range (≤25 dB) No air-bone gap Both curves would be close together in normal range
  • • Both air and bone conduction would be within normal range (≤25 dB)
  • • No air-bone gap
  • • Both curves would be close together in normal range

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds on pure tone audiometry is diagnostic of conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with hearing difficulty. On examination, the Rinne test is positive in the right ear and negative in the left ear. Weber's test shows lateralization to the right. Bone conduction is reduced in the left ear and normal in the right ear. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear

options.label: D
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The findings indicate severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear because:
  • • Left ear shows Rinne negative test (false negative) Weber lateralizes to right (better hearing) ear Reduced bone conduction in left ear confirms inner ear pathology This pattern occurs in severe unilateral SNHL where: Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing) Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL
  • • Left ear shows Rinne negative test (false negative)
  • • Weber lateralizes to right (better hearing) ear
  • • Reduced bone conduction in left ear confirms inner ear pathology
  • • This pattern occurs in severe unilateral SNHL where: Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing) Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL
  • • Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing) Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL
  • • Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing)
  • • Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction
  • • True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear
  • • Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
  • • Option A. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
  • • Would show true Rinne negative Weber would lateralize to affected (left) ear Bone conduction would be normal
  • • Would show true Rinne negative
  • • Weber would lateralize to affected (left) ear
  • • Bone conduction would be normal
  • • Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
  • • Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
  • • Rinne would be positive in right ear (correct) Weber would lateralize to left (unaffected) ear Bone conduction would be reduced in right ear
  • • Rinne would be positive in right ear (correct)
  • • Weber would lateralize to left (unaffected) ear
  • • Bone conduction would be reduced in right ear
  • • Option C. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
  • • Option C. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
  • • Rinne would be negative in right ear Weber would lateralize to right ear Bone conduction would be normal
  • • Rinne would be negative in right ear
  • • Weber would lateralize to right ear
  • • Bone conduction would be normal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative Rinne test with reduced bone conduction and Weber’s test lateralizing to the opposite ear suggests sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the affected ear.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with respiratory distress after a history of eating peanuts. Clinical examination reveals an audible thud during breathing. What is the most likely location of the foreign body? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trachea

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The foreign body is most likely in the trachea because:
  • • Presence of audible thud during breathing is pathognomonic of tracheal foreign body Foreign body in trachea moves up and down with respiration causing the thud sound Peanuts are common aspirated foreign bodies in children Acute presentation with respiratory distress after eating suggests aspiration History of eating peanuts followed by immediate symptoms suggests aspiration pathway rather than ingestion
  • • Presence of audible thud during breathing is pathognomonic of tracheal foreign body
  • • Foreign body in trachea moves up and down with respiration causing the thud sound
  • • Peanuts are common aspirated foreign bodies in children
  • • Acute presentation with respiratory distress after eating suggests aspiration
  • • History of eating peanuts followed by immediate symptoms suggests aspiration pathway rather than ingestion
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Larynx
  • • Option A. Larynx
  • • Would cause immediate severe respiratory distress Stridor would be prominent Voice changes would be present Less likely to cause thud sound
  • • Would cause immediate severe respiratory distress
  • • Stridor would be prominent
  • • Voice changes would be present
  • • Less likely to cause thud sound
  • • Option B. Bronchus
  • • Option B. Bronchus
  • • More common final location but doesn't cause thud sound Usually right main bronchus due to anatomical orientation Would cause unilateral wheeze or decreased breath sounds No up and down movement to cause thud
  • • More common final location but doesn't cause thud sound
  • • Usually right main bronchus due to anatomical orientation
  • • Would cause unilateral wheeze or decreased breath sounds
  • • No up and down movement to cause thud
  • • Option D. Oesophagus
  • • Option D. Oesophagus
  • • Would cause dysphagia rather than respiratory distress No audible thud during breathing Drooling and inability to swallow would be prominent Different management approach required
  • • Would cause dysphagia rather than respiratory distress
  • • No audible thud during breathing
  • • Drooling and inability to swallow would be prominent
  • • Different management approach required

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Foreign bodies in the trachea cause biphasic stridor and audible thuds due to partial airway obstruction. Immediate intervention with bronchoscopy is required to prevent asphyxiation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with respiratory distress, coughing, and an inability to speak after eating. What is the next best step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bronchoscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bronchoscopy is the best next step because:
  • • Child has already presented to the hospital with respiratory distress Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic Allows direct visualization of the foreign body Enables safe removal under controlled conditions Most appropriate for hospital setting where proper equipment and expertise are available Prevents complications from blind maneuvers
  • • Child has already presented to the hospital with respiratory distress
  • • Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic
  • • Allows direct visualization of the foreign body
  • • Enables safe removal under controlled conditions
  • • Most appropriate for hospital setting where proper equipment and expertise are available
  • • Prevents complications from blind maneuvers

  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Heimlich maneuver
  • • Option B. Heimlich maneuver
  • • More appropriate for immediate first aid in community setting Better suited for adults than children Risk of complications in young children Not the best choice once patient is in hospital
  • • More appropriate for immediate first aid in community setting
  • • Better suited for adults than children
  • • Risk of complications in young children
  • • Not the best choice once patient is in hospital

  • • Option C. Blind finger sweep
  • • Contraindicated in children Risk of pushing foreign body further down Can cause trauma to oropharynx May worsen the situation
  • • Contraindicated in children
  • • Risk of pushing foreign body further down
  • • Can cause trauma to oropharynx
  • • May worsen the situation
  • • Option D. Endotracheal intubation
  • • Option D. Endotracheal intubation
  • • Risk of pushing foreign body further down Doesn't address removal of foreign body May complicate the situation Not appropriate without first visualizing foreign body

  • • Not appropriate without first visualizing foreign body

  • ➤ Recognize that rigid bronchoscopy is the definitive management for foreign body aspiration in a hospital setting as it allows both diagnosis and therapeutic removal.

questions.text: Identify the following sign: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tear drop sign

  • • Shows herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus
  • • Appears as a tear-shaped shadow on imaging
  • • Characteristic finding in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • • Occurs due to disruption of orbital floor allowing downward displacement of orbital contents
  • • Important radiological sign in trauma cases
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:

  • • Option B. Steeple sign

  • • Appears as narrowing of upper airway
  • • Different radiological appearance

  • • Option C. Thumb sign
