questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoing hernia surgery was administered succinylcholine. After administration of anesthesia, he developed muscle rigidity, elevated temperature, and increased etCO2 levels. What is the appropriate treatment for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dantrolene sodium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dantrolene sodium is the specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia, a condition triggered by succinylcholine and inhalational anesthetics characterized by muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and increased etCO2.

questions.text: According to the latest AHA guidelines, what is the sixth link added to the "Chain of Survival" in CPR? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recovery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The American Heart Association (AHA) has updated the Chain of Survival to include a sixth link: Recovery. This emphasizes the importance of post-cardiac arrest rehabilitation, psychological support, and long-term follow-up.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following medications should be adjusted or stopped before the procedure? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stop Enalapril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Before surgery, ACE inhibitors like Enalapril should be stopped due to the risk of refractory hypotension, while beta-blockers can be continued, and aspirin should be managed based on its dosage.
  • ➤ Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives
  • ➤ Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives
  • ➤ ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery. Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery. Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery. Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery.
  • ➤ Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery.
  • ➤ Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ ANTICOAGULANTS
  • ➤ ANTICOAGULANTS
  • ➤ Aspirin continued on day of surgery Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.
  • ➤ Aspirin continued on day of surgery
  • ➤ Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery
  • ➤ Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery
  • ➤ Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery
  • ➤ LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery
  • ➤ Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery
  • ➤ BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.

questions.text: A child was intubated, and during auscultation, breath sounds were heard on the left side, but absent on the right side. What could be the most likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endobronchial intubation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endobronchial intubation occurs when the ETT is advanced too far into one bronchus, leading to ventilation of only one lung and collapse of the other. Proper technique, including auscultation and chest X-ray confirmation, is necessary to ensure correct ETT placement.
  • ➤ X RAY OF Endobronchial intubation
  • ➤ X RAY OF Endobronchial intubation

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with red, scaly rashes around the mouth and anus, a history of chronic diarrhoea, poor wound healing, and growth delay. Based on these symptoms, which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency should be suspected in pediatric patients presenting with perianal, perioral, and perivaginal rash, along with diarrhea and growth retardation. The condition, acrodermatitis enteropathica, requires zinc supplementation for treatment.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with complaints of fast breathing and distress. The image is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Croup

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) should be suspected in a child with barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and respiratory distress. The steeple sign on X-ray confirms the diagnosis. Management includes corticosteroids (dexamethasone) and nebulized epinephrine for severe cases.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is being screened for malnutrition at a health center. According to WHO criteria, what mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) measurement indicates severe acute malnutrition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) < 11.5 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm is one of the diagnostic criteria for severe acute malnutrition in children.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with disproportionate short stature with increased upper segment: lower segment ratio. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Achondroplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Achondroplasia presents with an increased upper segment:lower segment ratio due to short limbs with a relatively preserved trunk length. The condition is caused by an FGFR3 gene mutation and is the most common form of disproportionate short stature.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to bowing of the legs. On examination, the child has widening of the wrists and frontal bossing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickets should be suspected in children with bowing of the legs, delayed fontanelle closure, and widened wrists. It is caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to defective bone mineralization.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child came with complaints of fast breathing of RR 48 per minute with no chest in drawing. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pneumonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A respiratory rate of 48/min in a 2-year-old without chest indrawing is classified as pneumonia. IMNCI guidelines recommend oral amoxicillin for five days as the first-line treatment for non-severe pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not part of the classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hepatosplenomegaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital toxoplasmosis classically presents with the triad of chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. Additional findings such as hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and seizures may occur but are not part of the classic triad.

questions.text: Which anthropometric parameter indicates chronic malnutrition in a child according to WHO growth standards? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Height for age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic malnutrition is best measured by height-for-age, as it indicates long-term nutritional deficiencies leading to stunting. In contrast, weight-for-height reflects acute malnutrition (wasting), and weight-for-age is a mixed indicator.

questions.text: A baby presents with the clinical features shown in the image, including characteristic perioral and perianal rash along with a history of diarrhea, delayed wound healing. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zinc deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Remember the characteristic clinical presentation of zinc deficiency using the mnemonic "HIDE" - Healing (delayed), Immunity (decreased), Dermatitis (periorificial), and Enteropathy (diarrhea). The periorificial distribution of dermatitis is pathognomonic for zinc deficiency.

questions.text: A patient present with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classic triad of scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency): gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and petechiae/easy bruising. Understand that these symptoms occur due to impaired collagen synthesis and compromised blood vessel integrity.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is dependent on Vitamin C for its activity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prolyl hydroxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase, which is crucial for collagen synthesis and stability. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in scurvy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with black deposit in the vertebrae visible on X-Ray LS spine and also over knee joint and sclera which shows ochronosis. Which enzyme deficiency has caused this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Homogentisic acid oxidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria is caused by homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency and presents with ochronosis ( black deposits in connective tissues ) and darkening of urine on standing.
  • ➤ black deposits in connective tissues

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol consumption inhibits gluconeogenesis by creating a high NADH/NAD+ ratio, which depletes gluconeogenic substrates (pyruvate and oxaloacetate), potentially leading to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids primarily acts as a buffer in blood due to its ability to accept and donate protons at physiological pH? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Histidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histidine is the best amino acid buffer in blood because of its imidazole ring , which has a pKa close to physiological pH (~7).
  • ➤ Histidine is the best amino acid buffer in blood
  • ➤ imidazole ring
  • ➤ The imidazole group allows histidine to act as a proton donor or acceptor, making it an ideal buffer.
  • ➤ The imidazole group allows histidine to act as a proton donor or acceptor, making it an ideal buffer.

questions.text: Which of the following is accumulated in joint in the mucopolysaccharidosis associated with Natowicz disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyaluronic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Natowicz disease (MPS type IX) is characterized by hyaluronidase deficiency leading to accumulation of hyaluronic acid in joints, causing joint pain and short stature.
  • ➤ (MPS type IX)

questions.text: During starvation, which of the following hormones is primarily produced to maintain blood glucose levels? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucagon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucagon is the principal hormone responsible for maintaining blood glucose levels during starvation through activation of glycogenolysis , gluconeogenesis, and lipolysis . Its levels increase while insulin levels decrease during starvation.
  • ➤ activation of glycogenolysis
  • ➤ gluconeogenesis, and lipolysis
  • ➤ Hormonal Regulation During Starvation
  • ➤ Hormonal Regulation During Starvation

questions.text: The development of cataracts in patients with Diabetes Mellitus is primarily due to the accumulation of which of the following substances in the lens? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sorbitol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diabetic cataract ( snowflake cataract ) occurs due to sorbitol accumulation via the polyol pathway, whereas galactosemia leads to oil drop cataract due to galactitol/dulcitol accumulation.
  • ➤ snowflake cataract

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with obesity and developmental delay. It is caused by paternal deletion and imprinted maternal allele. Which chromosome is involved? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 15

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prader-Willi Syndrome involves chromosome 15, specifically:
  • ➤ Maternal allele is imprinted (naturally inhibited) Paternal allele deletion Results in both copies being non-functional
  • ➤ Maternal allele is imprinted (naturally inhibited)
  • ➤ Paternal allele deletion
  • ➤ Results in both copies being non-functional
  • ➤ For remembering deletion pattern:
  • ➤ For remembering deletion pattern:
  • ➤ "PAPA deleted in PWS"
  • ➤ "PAPA deleted in PWS"
  • ➤ Paternal deletion in Prader-Willi Syndrome
  • ➤ "Mothers are Angels"
  • ➤ "Mothers are Angels"
  • ➤ Angelman syndrome = Maternal deletion

questions.text: Which of the following is the marker of apoptosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phosphatidylserine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphatidylserine externalization is a specific marker of apoptosis and its role in recognition of apoptotic cells by phagocytes.
  • ➤ phagocytes.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for removal of Triglycerides from chylomicron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lipoprotein lipase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipoprotein lipase is the key enzyme responsible for hydrolyzing triglycerides from circulating chylomicrons and VLDL at the endothelial surface, facilitating fatty acid uptake by tissues.
  • ➤ chylomicrons and VLDL

questions.text: What enzyme analysis will be done in a patient before starting anti-malarial drugs who had a family history of hemolytic anemia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) G6PD analysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD analysis must be done before starting antimalarial therapy in patients with family history of hemolytic anemia, as G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder where antimalarial drugs can trigger severe hemolysis due to oxidative stress.

questions.text: A 40-year-old electrical worker is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a high-voltage electric shock at work. He reports muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine since the incident. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen muscles in the upper limbs. Laboratory tests show significantly elevated creatine kinase levels. What is the most likely substance found in his urine? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhabdomyolysis caused by muscle injury (such as electrical shock) leads to myoglobinuria, which causes dark-colored urine along with elevated serum creatine kinase levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is excreted in the urine of patients with Pentosuria? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) L xylulose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Biochemical Features of Pentosuria
  • ➤ Biochemical Features of Pentosuria

  • ➤ Reducing Sugar in Urine:

  • ➤ Clinical Symptoms:

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the regulation of enzyme activity through phosphorylation or dephosphorylation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Covalent modification

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphorylation/dephosphorylation represents a covalent modification mechanism for regulating enzyme activity through the addition or removal of phosphate groups.

questions.text: Acetyl CoA in prolonged starvation mostly will be used for: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ketogenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During prolonged starvation, acetyl CoA is primarily directed toward ketone body synthesis to provide alternative fuel for vital organs, rather than being used for anabolic processes like fatty acid or cholesterol synthesis.
  • ➤ Fates of Acetyl-CoA
  • ➤ Fates of Acetyl-CoA
  • ➤ In Starvation:
  • ➤ In Starvation:
  • ➤ TCA Cycle Ketone Body Synthesis Activation of Gluconeogenesis
  • ➤ TCA Cycle
  • ➤ Ketone Body Synthesis
  • ➤ Activation of Gluconeogenesis
  • ➤ In Fed State:
  • ➤ In Fed State:
  • ➤ Fatty Acid/TG (Triglyceride) Synthesis Cholesterol Synthesis TCA Cycle
  • ➤ Fatty Acid/TG (Triglyceride) Synthesis
  • ➤ Cholesterol Synthesis
  • ➤ TCA Cycle

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: pH -7.50; Pco2 –48mmHg; HCO3-30meq/l? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • pH is 7.5 (elevated above normal 7.35-7.45) indicating alkalosis PCO2 is 48 mmHg (elevated above normal 35-45 mmHg) indicating respiratory compensation HCO3 is 30 meq/L (elevated above normal 22-26 meq/L)
  • • pH is 7.5 (elevated above normal 7.35-7.45) indicating alkalosis
  • • PCO2 is 48 mmHg (elevated above normal 35-45 mmHg) indicating respiratory compensation
  • • HCO3 is 30 meq/L (elevated above normal 22-26 meq/L)
  • • This represents a primary metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation. The elevated HCO3 is the primary disorder causing the alkalosis. The elevated PCO2 represents appropriate respiratory compensation (hypoventilation) attempting to normalize the pH by retaining CO2.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: Incorrect because metabolic acidosis presents with low pH (<7.35) and low HCO3, which is opposite to the values given.
  • • Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis:Incorrect because respiratory alkalosis presents with high pH but low PCO2, whereas here PCO2 is elevated.
  • • Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis:Incorrect
  • • Option D. Respiratory Acidosis:Incorrect because respiratory acidosis presents with low pH and high PCO2. While PCO2 is high here, the pH is alkalotic rather than acidotic.
  • • Option D. Respiratory Acidosis:Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In arterial blood gas interpretation, metabolic alkalosis is characterized by:
  • ➤ Elevated pH (>7.45) Elevated HCO3 (>26 meq/L) Compensatory elevation in PCO2 through hypoventilation
  • ➤ Elevated pH (>7.45)
  • ➤ Elevated HCO3 (>26 meq/L)
  • ➤ Compensatory elevation in PCO2 through hypoventilation

questions.text: A person is exercising via performing different muscle movement, which of the following is correct regarding the muscle zone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Band I decreases

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During muscle contraction, the I band decreases in size due to increased overlapping between actin and myosin filaments. "When the muscle is going to start contracting, the overlapping between the actin and myosin is going to increase. And because of that, the I band (only actin) is going to decrease because more actin will be overlapped by the myosin."
  • • I band decreases in size due to increased overlapping between actin and myosin filaments.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. M-line decreases – Incorrect: The M line is the midline between two adjacent Z lines. "M line will never change" during muscle contraction. It remains constant as it's a structural component.
  • • Option A. M-line decreases – Incorrect:
  • • Option B. M-line & I band decreases - Incorrect : While I band does decrease, M line remains constant during contraction. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.
  • • Option B. M-line & I band decreases
  • • - Incorrect
  • • Option C. Band A decreases – Incorrect: A band represents the complete myosin filament length. "A band is a complete myosin that is nothing but whether it is overlapped by the actin or non-overlap does not matter. It will stay as it is." The A band length remains constant during contraction.
  • • Option C. Band A decreases – Incorrect:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During muscle contraction, while the M line and A band remain constant in length, the I band (containing only actin filaments) decreases in size due to increased actin-myosin overlap.

questions.text: Which one of the following leads to shift toward red curve in the given graph? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) shows the relationship between PO2 and hemoglobin saturation . The red curve in the image represents a right shift. Acidosis causes a right shift of the curve, known as the Bohr effect. When blood pH decreases (acidosis), the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen decreases, causing more oxygen to be released to the tissues. This is physiologically beneficial as tissues in acidotic conditions often need more oxygen.
  • • PO2 and hemoglobin saturation
  • • Bohr effect.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Less 2,3 BPG: Incorrect Less 2,3-BPG causes a left shift of the curve, not right
  • • Option B. Less 2,3 BPG: Incorrect
  • • When 2,3-BPG levels decrease, hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases This means oxygen binds more tightly to hemoglobin and less is released to tissues
  • • When 2,3-BPG levels decrease, hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases
  • • This means oxygen binds more tightly to hemoglobin and less is released to tissues
  • • Option C. Hypocarbia: Incorrect Hypocarbia means decreased CO2 levels
  • • Option C. Hypocarbia: Incorrect
  • • This leads to alkalosis which causes a left shift Results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen
  • • This leads to alkalosis which causes a left shift
  • • Results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen
  • • Option D. Hypothermia: Incorrect Lower temperature causes a left shift of the curve
  • • Option D. Hypothermia: Incorrect
  • • Increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen Reduces oxygen delivery to tissues
  • • Increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen
  • • Reduces oxygen delivery to tissues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acidosis causes a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (Bohr effect), while alkalosis, hypothermia, and decreased 2,3-BPG cause left shifts.

  • • They are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex Located in the Purkinje layer (between the molecular and granular layers) Organized in a single row Have distinctive large cell bodies and extensive dendritic trees They are the only output cells from the cerebellar cortex

  • • Have distinctive large cell bodies and extensive dendritic trees
  • • They are the only output cells from the cerebellar cortex

  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Basket cells: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Basket cells: Incorrect
  • • Because basket cells are smaller interneurons found in the molecular layer They make connections with Purkinje cell bodies They have a characteristic "basket-like" axonal arborization
  • • Because basket cells are smaller interneurons found in the molecular layer
  • • smaller interneurons found in the molecular layer
  • • They make connections with Purkinje cell bodies
  • • They have a characteristic "basket-like" axonal arborization
  • • "basket-like"
  • • Option C. Granule cells: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Granule cells: Incorrect
  • • Because granule cells are the smallest and most numerous neurons in the cerebellum They are located in the granular layer (seen as the dense purple layer in the image) They have small round cell bodies
  • • Because granule cells are the smallest and most numerous neurons in the cerebellum
  • • smallest and most numerous neurons
  • • They are located in the granular layer (seen as the dense purple layer in the image)
  • • granular layer
  • • They have small round cell bodies
  • • Option D. Golgi cells: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Golgi cells: Incorrect
  • • Because Golgi cells are interneurons present in the granular layer They are involved in local circuit processing They do not have the characteristic large cell body and location seen in the image
  • • Because Golgi cells are interneurons present in the granular layer
  • • Golgi cells are interneurons present in the granular layer
  • • They are involved in local circuit processing
  • • They do not have the characteristic large cell body and location seen in the image

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex, arranged in a single layer between molecular and granular layers, and serve as the sole output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

  • ➤ cerebellar cortex,
  • ➤ molecular and granular layers,

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Mechanism of botulinum toxin: (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

questions.correct_answer: A. Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting acetylcholine release from presynaptic terminals. It specifically acts by:
  • • Inhibiting Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex SNARE proteins are essential for neurotransmitter exocytosis This inhibition prevents acetylcholine release into the synaptic cleft Results in flaccid paralysis due to lack of neurotransmitter release Clinically used in treating conditions like achalasia cardia, spasms, and contractures
  • • Inhibiting Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex
  • • Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex
  • • SNARE proteins are essential for neurotransmitter exocytosis
  • • neurotransmitter exocytosis
  • • This inhibition prevents acetylcholine release into the synaptic cleft
  • • Results in flaccid paralysis due to lack of neurotransmitter release
  • • Clinically used in treating conditions like achalasia cardia, spasms, and contractures
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Inhibit Acetylcholine reuptake: Incorrect because botulinum toxin doesn't affect reuptake mechanisms. It acts specifically on the release mechanism.
  • • Option B. Inhibit Acetylcholine reuptake: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Block post synaptic Acetylcholine receptor: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action for myasthenia gravis where antibodies target post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. Botulinum toxin acts presynaptically.
  • • Option C. Block post synaptic Acetylcholine receptor: Incorrect.
  • • Option D. Inhibit Acetylcholine esterase: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action of drugs like neostigmine and pyridostigmine used in treating myasthenia gravis. They prevent the breakdown of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.
  • • Option D. Inhibit Acetylcholine esterase: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin functions by inhibiting acetylcholine release through its action on SNARE proteins (specifically synaptobrevin ) at the presynaptic terminal.
  • ➤ SNARE proteins (specifically synaptobrevin

questions.text: In JVP ‘a ‘wave represents which one of the following? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: C
options.text: Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right atrial contraction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The a-wave in the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to atrial contraction . When the right atrium contracts , it causes an increase in pressure that is transmitted backward into the jugular veins, creating the a-wave . This wave appears just before the carotid pulse and first heart sound (S1). The a-wave is one of the most easily visible waves in the JVP examination and is particularly important because its presence confirms that the patient is in sinus rhythm, as it indicates normal atrial contraction.
  • • atrial contraction
  • • right atrium contracts
  • • a-wave
  • • carotid pulse and first heart sound (S1).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Right atrial relaxation: Incorrect. Right atrial relaxation is represented by the 'x' descent in JVP, not the 'a' wave.
  • • Option B. Right atrial relaxation: Incorrect.
  • • Option C. Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria: Incorrect. This is represented by the 'c' wave in JVP, which occurs when the tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium during early ventricular systole.
  • • Option C. Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria: Incorrect.
  • • Option D. Right atrial filling: Incorrect . Right atrial filling is represented by the 'v' wave in JVP, which occurs during venous return when the tricuspid valve is closed.
  • • Option D. Right atrial filling: Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ a-wave in the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to atrial contraction and understand its clinical significance in assessing cardiac rhythm and right heart function.
  • ➤ a-wave in the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to atrial contraction

questions.text: Which one of the following is related to the release of bicarbonate in exchange of Chloride in the RBC? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chloride shift

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chloride shift (also known as Hamburger phenomenon ) occurs when RBCs move towards the tissue. As RBCs enter venous blood, CO2 diffuses into them and combines with H2O to form H2CO3 under the influence of carbonic anhydrase. H2CO3 dissociates into H+ and HCO3-. The bicarbonate ion is then exchanged for chloride through an exchanger protein . When chloride enters the RBC, water follows due to osmosis, causing the RBCs to swell. This increases the hematocrit in venous blood compared to arterial blood.
  • • Hamburger phenomenon
  • • chloride through an exchanger protein
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Bohr's effect: Incorrect. Because Bohr's effect refers to the right shift of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve due to increased CO2, decreased pH, or increased temperature, leading to enhanced oxygen unloading in tissues.
  • • Option A. Bohr's effect: Incorrect.
  • • Option B. Haldane effect: Incorrect. Because Haldane effect describes the enhanced unloading of CO2 in the lungs due to increased oxygenation of hemoglobin. It represents the left shift of the curve in lungs.
  • • Option B. Haldane effect: Incorrect.
  • • Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Because chloride shift is the correct phenomenon describing the exchange of bicarbonate and chloride in RBCs.
  • • Option D. None of the above: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chloride shift (Hamburger phenomenon) involves the exchange of bicarbonate ions for chloride ions across the RBC membrane during tissue gas exchange, leading to increased RBC volume in venous blood.

questions.text: In a patient after giving a Noradrenaline injection heart rate started to decrease, what is the reason for it: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stimulation of Baroreceptor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When noradrenaline (a sympathetic agent) is administered, it activates the sympathetic system leading to an increase in blood pressure. This increased blood pressure activates baroreceptors, triggering a reflex response. Since noradrenaline has already bound to its receptors and cannot decrease blood pressure directly, the body activates the cardio inhibitory center (CIC) to inhibit the SA node . This inhibition leads to bradycardia, known as reflex bradycardia. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain blood pressure homeostasis.
  • • baroreceptors,
  • • cardio inhibitory center (CIC)
  • • SA node
  • • homeostasis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Stimulation of alpha 2 receptors: Incorrect because heart does not have alpha 2 receptors. Alpha receptors are primarily involved in vasoconstriction.
  • • Option A. Stimulation of alpha 2 receptors: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Stimulation of beta 1 receptors: Incorrect because beta 1 receptor stimulation would cause an increase in heart rate (tachycardia), not a decrease.
  • • Option C. Stimulation of beta 1 receptors: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Inhibition of Baroreceptor: Incorrect because inhibition of baroreceptors would lead to tachycardia, not bradycardia. Baroreceptor inhibition removes the "brake" on heart rate.
  • • Option D. Inhibition of Baroreceptor: Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Baroreceptor stimulation due to increased blood pressure can cause reflex bradycardia as a compensatory mechanism, even when using sympathetic agents like noradrenaline.
  • ➤ reflex bradycardia as a compensatory mechanism,
  • ➤ noradrenaline.

questions.text: In Presence of ADH, Maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid will be in which of the following site of nephron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Medullary CD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ADH increases water permeability in the collecting ducts by inserting aquaporin channels. When ADH is present, as we move from the cortex towards the deep medulla, osmolarity keeps increasing. Though ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum change in osmolarity occurs in the medullary region due to the countercurrent multiplication system maintaining high osmolarity in the medullary interstitium.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. PCT: Incorrect because PCT mainly handles obligatory water reabsorption (60-70%) through osmosis, not regulated by ADH.
  • • Option A. PCT: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Cortical CD: Incorrect because although ADH acts here, the osmotic gradient in the cortex is much lower than in the medulla.
  • • Option B. Cortical CD: Incorrect
  • • Option C. DCT: Incorrect because DCT has minimal water reabsorption (1-3%) without ADH and is not a major site for ADH action.
  • • Option C. DCT: Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid is achieved in the medullary collecting duct due to the high osmotic gradient maintained by the countercurrent multiplication system in the medulla.

questions.text: Which hormone is involved in the given scenario shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxytocin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows breastfeeding, which involves the milk ejection/letdown reflex mediated by oxytocin. This is a positive feedback mechanism where suckling stimulates the release of oxytocin. milk letdown reflex is one of the classic examples of positive feedback mechanisms in the body (along with other "HCLAMP" mechanisms - Hodgkin's cycle, Clotting cascade, LH surge, Activation of digestive enzymes, Milk letdown, and Parturition reflex).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Adrenaline: Incorrect because adrenaline is a stress hormone released from adrenal medulla. It has no direct role in milk ejection/breastfeeding.
  • • Option B. Adrenaline: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Cortisol: Incorrect because cortisol is a glucocorticoid involved in stress response and metabolism. While it may be present during breastfeeding, it is not the primary hormone responsible for milk ejection.
  • • Option C. Cortisol: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Thyroxin: Incorrect because thyroxine is involved in metabolism and growth. While it plays a supportive role in lactation by maintaining metabolic rate, it is not directly responsible for milk ejection during breastfeeding.
  • • Option D. Thyroxin: Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxytocin is the key hormone responsible for milk ejection/letdown reflex during breastfeeding through a positive feedback mechanism.

questions.text: Dehydration usually affects an infant’s more than adults. Which of the following is a true statement in this scenario related to infants / Newborn? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: C
options.text: Total body water is more than adults

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ECF more than ICF

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In newborns/infants, the ECF is greater than ICF, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration.
  • • ECF is greater than ICF in newborns At 3-4 months of age, ICF equals ECF (50:50) After 3-4 months, ICF gradually increases while ECF decreases This higher ECF makes infants more vulnerable to fluid losses and dehydration
  • • ECF is greater than ICF in newborns
  • • At 3-4 months of age, ICF equals ECF (50:50)
  • • After 3-4 months, ICF gradually increases while ECF decreases
  • • This higher ECF makes infants more vulnerable to fluid losses and dehydration
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ICF more than ECF: Incorrect. Because in newborns, ECF is higher than ICF. ICF becomes greater than ECF only after 3-4 months of age.
  • • Option B. ICF more than ECF: Incorrect.
  • • Option C. Total body water is more than adults: Incorrect. Because while newborns have a higher percentage of total body water (75%) compared to adults (60%), the absolute amount of water is less in newborns due to their smaller body size.
  • • Option C. Total body water is more than adults: Incorrect.
  • • Option D. ECF equals ICF: Incorrect. Because ECF equals ICF only at around 3-4 months of age, not in newborns.
  • • Option D. ECF equals ICF: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In newborns, extracellular fluid (ECF) volume is greater than intracellular fluid (ICF) volume, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration compared to adults.

questions.text: FSH is inhibited by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inhibin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • FSH is inhibited by inhibin . This is a direct feedback mechanism where:
  • • FSH
  • • inhibin
  • • Inhibin is produced by the gonads (Sertoli cells in males and granulosa cells in females) It specifically inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary This creates a negative feedback loop that helps regulate FSH levels
  • • Inhibin is produced by the gonads (Sertoli cells in males and granulosa cells in females)
  • • It specifically inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary
  • • This creates a negative feedback loop that helps regulate FSH levels
  • • Other Options:

  • • Option B. Estrogen Incorrect because estrogen is stimulated by FSH, not the other way around. FSH stimulates estrogen production from ovarian follicles.
  • • Option B. Estrogen Incorrect
  • • Option C. Progesterone Incorrect because progesterone doesn't directly inhibit FSH. While progesterone can affect the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, it's not the primary inhibitor of FSH.
  • • Option C. Progesterone Incorrect
  • • Option D. Testosterone Incorrect because testosterone doesn't directly inhibit FSH. While testosterone can affect the hypothalamic-pituitary axis through negative feedback, it's not the primary inhibitor of FSH.
  • • Option D. Testosterone Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibin is the primary and specific inhibitor of FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary gland.

questions.text: A patient with the respiratory difficulty and had a history of Chronic smoking. His pulmonary function testing showed decrease FEV1 %. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)

According to GOLD criteria , post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% confirms the presence of persistent airflow limitation and COPD diagnosis in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.
  • • Decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic criteria for airflow obstruction/Obstructive disease) Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response(distinguishes from asthma very good improvement in FEV1) . According to GOLD criteria , post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% confirms the presence of persistent airflow limitation and COPD diagnosis in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.
  • • Decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic criteria for airflow obstruction/Obstructive disease)
  • • Decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio <70%
  • • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response(distinguishes from asthma very good improvement in FEV1) .

  • • response(distinguishes from asthma very good improvement in FEV1) .
  • • According to GOLD criteria , post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% confirms the presence of persistent airflow limitation and COPD diagnosis in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.
  • • GOLD criteria
  • • FEV1/FVC ratio <70% confirms
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis shows a restrictive pattern on PFTs with FEV1/FVC ratio >70% and reduced total lung capacity, not an obstructive pattern as seen here.
  • • Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect

questions.text: Test results of a hypertensive patient shows Hypernatremia, hypokalemia, alkalosis. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is characterized by autonomous aldosterone secretion causing:
  • • Hypernatremia due to increased Na+ reabsorption Hypokalemia due to increased K+ excretion Metabolic alkalosis due to increased H+ secretion and HCO3- reabsorption Hypertension due to Na+ and water retention
  • • Hypernatremia due to increased Na+ reabsorption
  • • Hypokalemia due to increased K+ excretion
  • • Metabolic alkalosis due to increased H+ secretion and HCO3- reabsorption
  • • Hypertension due to Na+ and water retention
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Addison's disease - Incorrect because:
  • • Option B. Addison's disease - Incorrect because:
  • • Characterized by aldosterone deficiency leading to hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis Presents with hypotension, not hypertension
  • • Characterized by aldosterone deficiency leading to hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis
  • • Presents with hypotension, not hypertension
  • • Option C. Diabetes Insipidus - Incorrect because:
  • • Option C. Diabetes Insipidus - Incorrect because:
  • • Primarily affects water balance causing hypernatremia but without significant effects on K+ or acid-base balance No direct effect on blood pressure
  • • Primarily affects water balance causing hypernatremia but without significant effects on K+ or acid-base balance
  • • No direct effect on blood pressure
  • • Option D. Cushing's disease - Incorrect because:
  • • Option D. Cushing's disease - Incorrect because:
  • • While it can cause hypertension, the primary abnormalities are related to excess cortisol Does not typically cause significant electrolyte disturbances like hypokalemia
  • • While it can cause hypertension, the primary abnormalities are related to excess cortisol
  • • Does not typically cause significant electrolyte disturbances like hypokalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome) presents with the triad of:
  • ➤ Hypernatremia Hypokalemia Metabolic alkalosis Along with hypertension due to mineralocorticoid excess.
  • ➤ Hypernatremia
  • ➤ Hypokalemia
  • ➤ Metabolic alkalosis Along with hypertension due to mineralocorticoid excess.

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty switching from one movement to another, along with uncontrollable hand movements. Identify the abnormality: (FMGE JAN 2025)

Ans. A) Dysdiadochokinesia

  • • Di
  • • Docho: alternate
  • • Docho:

  • • Kinesis:

questions.text: A factory worker is exposed to phosphine gas during a pesticide fumigation process. He develops nausea, vomiting, dyspnea, and hypotension. Phosphine gas primarily causes which type of hypoxia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Histotoxic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase activity in the tissues. This leads to:
  • • Decreased oxygen uptake by the tissues Reduced mitochondrial function Inability of cells to utilize available oxygen Normal oxygen content in blood but tissues cannot use it Results in cellular hypoxia despite adequate oxygen delivery
  • • Decreased oxygen uptake by the tissues
  • • Reduced mitochondrial function
  • • Inability of cells to utilize available oxygen
  • • Normal oxygen content in blood but tissues cannot use it
  • • Results in cellular hypoxia despite adequate oxygen delivery
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anaemic Hypoxia: Incorrect
  • • Option A. Anaemic Hypoxia: Incorrect
  • • Occurs due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood Normal alveolar oxygen but reduced hemoglobin or abnormal hemoglobin Examples: Anemia, CO poisoning, methemoglobinemia Not relevant here as phosphine doesn't affect hemoglobin
  • • Occurs due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood
  • • Normal alveolar oxygen but reduced hemoglobin or abnormal hemoglobin
  • • Examples: Anemia, CO poisoning, methemoglobinemia
  • • Not relevant here as phosphine doesn't affect hemoglobin
  • • Option B. Hypoxic Hypoxia: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Hypoxic Hypoxia: Incorrect
  • • Results from low atmospheric partial pressure of oxygen Reduced oxygen gradient towards alveoli and pulmonary capillaries Examples: High altitude, diffusion disorders, fibrosis Phosphine doesn't affect atmospheric or alveolar oxygen levels
  • • Results from low atmospheric partial pressure of oxygen
  • • Reduced oxygen gradient towards alveoli and pulmonary capillaries
  • • Examples: High altitude, diffusion disorders, fibrosis
  • • Phosphine doesn't affect atmospheric or alveolar oxygen levels
  • • Option D. Stagnant Hypoxia: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Stagnant Hypoxia: Incorrect
  • • Due to reduced blood flow/circulation Normal atmospheric oxygen, alveoli, and hemoglobin Occurs in circulatory failure Phosphine primarily affects cellular oxygen utilization, not circulation
  • • Due to reduced blood flow/circulation
  • • Normal atmospheric oxygen, alveoli, and hemoglobin
  • • Occurs in circulatory failure
  • • Phosphine primarily affects cellular oxygen utilization, not circulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondria, preventing cellular oxygen utilization despite normal oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: A patient presents with linear nodular lesions extending along the lymphatic drainage after sustaining a rose thorn injury. Examination reveals a chain of linear subcutaneous granulomas. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)

Diagnosis is confirmed by culture on Sabouraud’s agar , and treatment is typically oral itraconazole for mild cases or amphotericin B for severe infections.

  • ➤ amphotericin B

questions.text: A guy gets beaten up by 4-5 people and comes to the hospital with serious injuries. He decides to give a dying declaration. Which of the following is true for a dying declaration in India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oath not taken

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A dying declaration is the statement made by a person on their deathbed regarding the cause of their death or the circumstances leading to it. In India, it holds significant evidentiary value in a court of law. The aspects of a dying declaration include:
  • • dying declaration
  • • Oath is not taken: Unlike a court deposition where witnesses take an oath before testifying, a dying declaration does not require an oath. This is because the fundamental assumption is that a dying person is unlikely to lie. Anyone can record it: Although a magistrate is preferred, if the victim is in a critical condition and a magistrate is unavailable, a doctor, police officer, or any responsible person can record the statement. No cross-examination: Unlike a dying deposition , a dying declaration is a direct statement of the victim and is not subjected to cross-examination. Leading questions are not allowed: The person recording the dying declaration should only document what the victim states, without suggesting or influencing their answers.

questions.text: A lady died under unnatural death within 3 years of marriage. Who will do the inquest? (FMGE JAN 2025)

  • • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage Death is unnatural Death has association with dowry allegations This comes under Section 196 BNSS (previously 176 CrPC) and is one of the three specific conditions requiring magistrate inquest along with custodial deaths and exhumation.
  • • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage
  • • Death is unnatural

  • • Option C. Advocate
  • • Option D. Coroner: Incorrect Coroner system is not practiced in India. It was previously followed in some cities like Mumbai but has been abolished. Coroner system is currently practiced in countries like UK and USA.

questions.text: A forensic doctor is facing criminal charges for malpractice in a district criminal court and is also summoned to provide expert testimony in a district civil court for which he will be provided compensation. What is the correct statement in this scenario? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: C
options.text: Attend the summon which was received earlier

options.label: D
options.text: Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Attend Criminal Court

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When receiving summons from multiple courts, the priority is determined by the following factors:
  • • Court Rank : Higher courts take precedence over lower courts. Case Type : Criminal cases are prioritized over civil cases. The ranking of the court is more significant than the type of case. For instance, if one summons is from a higher court for a civil case and another is from a lower court for a criminal case, the higher court should be attended. Timeliness : If both court rank and case type are the same, the court whose summons was received first should be attended.
  • • Court Rank : Higher courts take precedence over lower courts.
  • • Court Rank
  • • Case Type : Criminal cases are prioritized over civil cases. The ranking of the court is more significant than the type of case. For instance, if one summons is from a higher court for a civil case and another is from a lower court for a criminal case, the higher court should be attended.
  • • Case Type
  • • Timeliness : If both court rank and case type are the same, the court whose summons was received first should be attended.
  • • Timeliness
  • • In this case:
  • • Both courts are of same rank (district court) One case is criminal and other is civil Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases even if compensation is offered
  • • Both courts are of same rank (district court)
  • • One case is criminal and other is civil
  • • Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases even if compensation is offered
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Attend Civil Court: Incorrect. Even though compensation is offered, civil court attendance does not take precedence over criminal court when summons are received simultaneously.
  • • Option B. Attend Civil Court:
  • • Option C. Attend the summon which was received earlier: Incorrect. While timing of summons receipt is a criterion, it only applies when both courts are of same rank and type. Criminal cases take precedence regardless of when summons was received.
  • • Option C. Attend the summon which was received earlier:
  • • Option D. Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon: Incorrect. Ignoring court summons and waiting for second summons is not appropriate. One must attend according to the priority.
  • • Option D. Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon:

  • • Scab begins to peel off

questions.text: Corneal transplant is allowed until how much time after death? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 6 hours

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • While most organs can be transplanted, only while body is still on ventilator, and blood circulation is maintained, in case of cornea, the transplantation is possible even if a person is died at home because cornea is avascular (lacks blood supply) It Can be done up to 6 hours after death in India In western countries, can be extended up to 12 hours Time limit is shorter in India due to tropical climate causing faster decomposition Other organs require continuous blood supply and must be harvested while patient is on ventilator
  • • While most organs can be transplanted, only while body is still on ventilator, and blood circulation is maintained, in case of cornea, the transplantation is possible even if a person is died at home because cornea is avascular (lacks blood supply)
  • • It Can be done up to 6 hours after death in India
  • • In western countries, can be extended up to 12 hours
  • • Time limit is shorter in India due to tropical climate causing faster decomposition
  • • Other organs require continuous blood supply and must be harvested while patient is on ventilator
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. Corneas do not deteriorate this quickly and can be used for transplantation for several hours post-mortem.
  • • Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect.
  • • do not deteriorate this quickly
  • • Option B. 2 hours: Incorrect. The minimum accepted timeframe is up to 6 hours , not just 2 hours.
  • • Option B. 2 hours: Incorrect.
  • • minimum accepted timeframe is up to 6 hours
  • • Option C. 4 hours: Incorrect. Though corneal tissue remains viable for more than 4 hours , the standard practice extends the limit up to 6 hours in India.
  • • Option C. 4 hours: Incorrect.
  • • more than 4 hours
  • • up to 6 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A corneal transplant can be performed within 6 hours after death because the cornea is avascular and does not deteriorate as rapidly as other organs​
  • ➤ corneal transplant
  • ➤ within 6 hours after death
  • ➤ cornea is avascular

questions.text: After a myocardial infarction (MI), staining was done using Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) Most myocardial tissue got stained in brick red color, while some tissue remained pale. What is the minimum survival time required post MI for this color change to appear? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2-3 hours

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) test is used to detect early myocardial infarction (MI) by staining viable cardiac tissue.
  • • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 12 hours for any gross changes in the heart to be visible. The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 6 hours for any microscopic changes in the heart to be visible.
  • • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 12 hours for any gross changes in the heart to be visible.
  • • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 6 hours for any microscopic changes in the heart to be visible.
  • • However, with the use of TTC staining , gross changes in the heart can be observed as early as 2-3 hours post-MI.
  • • with the use of TTC staining
  • • In normal tissue , mitochondrial enzymes such as dehydrogenases are present, which reduce TTC, resulting in a brick-red color. In infarcted tissue , the infarcted area remains pale due to the absence of these mitochondrial enzymes, which are affected by the lack of blood supply. Complete mitochondrial enzyme death typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time, post-MI.
  • • In normal tissue , mitochondrial enzymes such as dehydrogenases are present, which reduce TTC, resulting in a brick-red color.
  • • normal tissue
  • • In infarcted tissue , the infarcted area remains pale due to the absence of these mitochondrial enzymes, which are affected by the lack of blood supply.
  • • infarcted tissue
  • • Complete mitochondrial enzyme death typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time, post-MI.
  • • Complete mitochondrial enzyme death
  • • Other Option :
  • • Other Option
  • • Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. The TTC reaction typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time after MI for a clear distinction between infarcted and normal tissue to be visible.
  • • Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect.
  • • at least 2-3 hours
  • • Option C. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. While TTC can detect MI after 2-3 hours, the question specifically asks about the minimum time , not a broader window.
  • • Option C. 6-12 hours: Incorrect.
  • • minimum time
  • • Option D. > 24 hours: Incorrect. The TTC test can detect MI much earlier than 24 hours. The question is asking about the minimum time needed for the color change to appear.
  • • Option D. > 24 hours: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The TTC test is used to detect early MI. A brick-red color appears in viable myocardium, while the infarcted area remains pale after 2-3 hours post-MI.
  • ➤ brick-red color
  • ➤ 2-3 hours
  • ➤ Note that some sources suggest a minimum survival time of 4 hours for TTC positivity instead of 2-3 hours.

questions.text: A young male patient, aged 20, presents with increasing localized pain that developed gradually over time. Imaging via X-ray revealed sunray appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Osteosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer, and it often presents in adolescents and young adults (like this 20-year-old patient). A "sunray appearance" on X-ray is a classic sign of osteosarcoma, where bony spicules radiate outward from the tumor.
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer, and it often presents in adolescents and young adults (like this 20-year-old patient).
  • ➤ A "sunray appearance" on X-ray is a classic sign of osteosarcoma, where bony spicules radiate outward from the tumor.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely affected, based on the hand posture shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4 th and 5 th digits. This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.
  • ➤ The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4 th and 5 th digits.
  • ➤ This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • ➤ Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below in a patient who presented with a history of fall. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior shoulder dislocation

In the posterior dislocation, on x-ray, the humeral head is up and in i.e., lying above the glenoid with the arm adducted.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female labourer complains of soft, fluctuating swelling in front of the knee, directly over the patella. She reports discomfort and difficulty while moving her knee. MRI results confirm the findings. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Housemaid’s knee

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The given image shows an inflammation anterior to the patella.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with bow legs and on x-ray of wrist, following were the findings. The child also had low serum calcium and low serum phosphate values. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image of the child’s hands and wrists shows cupping and splaying of the radius and the ulna. The patient presents with bow legs, and decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate. These are common findings of rickets caused by defective bone mineralization or nutritional deficiency of vitamin D in children.
  • ➤ The given image of the child’s hands and wrists shows cupping and splaying of the radius and the ulna.
  • ➤ The patient presents with bow legs, and decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate.
  • ➤ These are common findings of rickets caused by defective bone mineralization or nutritional deficiency of vitamin D in children.
